Replies.Reply: TS Eliot. Not the first person to say it, certainly not the first person to think it.
But he's given credit for it because he bothered to write it down.
So if you say it, you have to say his name after it. "Life is very long:" TS Eliot. Absolutely goddamn right.
Not hard to imagine, faced with Eliot's first wife, lovely Viv, how Crane or Berryman might have reacted, just foot-raced to the nearest bridge; Olympian Suicidalists.
Not Eliot: after sufficient years of ecclesiastical guilt, plop her in the nearest asylum and get on with it.
God-a-mighty. You have to admire the purity of the survivor's instinct.
My wife takes pills and I drink.
The reasons why we partake are anymore inconsequential.
Rather than once more vow abstinence with my fingers crossed in the queasy hope of righting our ship, I've chosen to turn my life over to a Higher Power and join the ranks of the Hiring Class.
It's not a decision with which I'm entirely comfortable. I know how to launder my dirty undies. Done it all my life, but I'm finding it's getting in the way of my drinking.
May I ask how?
Wine grapes. In Oklahoma.   I'm sorry.
Yes?
Can you come here?
Johnna, the young woman I told you about.
That I'm hiring --
To cook and clean, take you to the clinic and to the --
I don't understand you.
Why don't you go back to bed, sweetheart?
All right.
We keep unusual hours here. Try not to differentiate between night and day. You won't be able to keep a healthy routine.

I myself require very little attention, thrive without it, sort of a human cactus. My wife has been diagnosed with a touch of cancer, so she'll need to be driven to Tulsa for her final chemotherapy treatments.
My God, I nearly neglected the punch line: mouth cancer.
Valium. Vicodin. Darvon, Darvocet.
"By night within that ancient house, Immense, black, damned, anonymous."
My last refuge, my books: simple pleasures, like finding wild onions by the side of a road, or requited love.

Goddamn your father for putting me through this. Seen that office of his, all that mess? I can't make heads or tails of it. He hired this Indian for some goddamn reason and now I have a stranger in my house. What's her name?
This house is falling apart, something about the basement or the sump pump or the foundation. I don't know anything about it. I can't do this by myself.
What did she say?
She'll be a big fat help, just like you.
I need Barb.
What did you do to your hair?
You had it straightened.    Why would anybody do that?
You're the prettiest of my three girls, but you always look like a schlub. Why don't you wear makeup?
All women need makeup. Don't let anybody tell you different. The only woman who was pretty enough to go without makeup was Elizabeth Taylor and she wore a ton. Stand up straight.
Your shoulders are slumped and your hair's all straight and you don't wear makeup. You look like a lesbian.
You could get a decent man if you spruced up. A bit, that's all I'm saying.
There are a lot of losers out there, don't think I don't know that. But just because you got a bad one last time doesn't mean --
Barry was an asshole. I warned you from the jump, first time you brought him over here in his little electric car with his stupid orange hair and that turban --
You work at a college. Don't tell me there aren't people coming through the door of that library every day.
They still have teachers at TU, right?
How many was that?
Like a son-of-a-bitch.   My tongue is on fire.

No, that's where what's-her-name lives.
She's the Indian who lives in my attic.
Saturday morning. The Indian girl made us biscuits and gravy. We ate some, he walked out the door, this door right there. Got into his truck. And that was it.

She's a stranger in my house. There's an Indian in my house.

I'm sure you'd prefer to think that Santy Claus brought you presents at Christmas, too. If you'd had more than one child, you'd know a parent always has favorites. Mattie Fae was my mother's favorite. Big deal. I got used to it. You were your Daddy's favorite.
Broke his heart.
You're wrong there. You never would've gotten Beverly Weston out of Oklahoma.
Beverly didn't say terrible things behind your back --
Oh, horseshit, horseshit, let's all say horseshit. Say horseshit, Bill.

All this shit's going. I don't plan to spend the rest of my days looking at what used to be. I want that shit in the office gone, I want these clothes I'm never going to wear gone.
Look at me.
Look at me.
I was beautiful. Not anymore.

One of those lies we tell to give us comfort. Women are beautiful when they're young and not after. Men can still preserve their sex appeal into old age. Not those men like you see with shorts and those little purses around their waists. Some men can maintain a weary masculinity. Women just get old and fat and wrinkly.

The world is round. Get over it.

Bev made some good investments, believe it or not, and we had money for you girls in his will, but we talked it over after some years passed and decided to change things, leave everything to me. We never got around to taking care of it legally, but you should know he meant to leave the money to me.
Okay?

here and that man we buried today!

In a Pontiac Sedan. With his mother, his father, in a fucking car! Now what do you want to say about your rotten childhood? That's the crux of the biscuit: we lived too hard, then rose too high. We sacrificed everything and we did it all for you.

away from me and I'll eat you alive.

I ever tell you the story of Raymond Qualls? Not much story to it. Boy I had a crush on when I was thirteen or so. Rough-looking boy, beat-up Levis, messy hair. Terrible underbite.

But he had these beautiful cowboy boots, shiny chocolate leather. He was so proud of those boots, you could tell, way he'd strut around, all arms and elbows, puffed up and cocksure. I decided I needed to get a girly pair of those same boots and I convinced myself he'd ask me to go steady. He'd see me in those boots and say "Now there's the gal for me."

Found the boots in a window downtown and just went crazy: praying for those boots, rehearsing the conversation I'd have with Raymond when he saw me in my boots. Must've asked my momma a hundred times if I could get those boots. "What do you want for Christmas, Vi?" "Momma, I'll give all of it up just for those boots."
Oh, no.   That's the end.

Come on now --

Oh sure. I never told them I knew.
I called over there on Monday after I got into that safety deposit box. But it was too late, he'd checked out.

Barbara stares at her mother for a long moment.       Then --

You'd better understand this, you smug little ingrate. There's only one reason Beverly killed himself and that's you. Think there's any way he would've done what he did if you were still here? No, just him and me, here in this house, in the dark, left to ourselves, abandoned, wasted lifetimes devoted to your care and comfort.
So stick that knife of judgment in me, go ahead, but make no mistake, his blood is just as much on your hands as it is on mine.

He did this though, not us. Can you imagine anything more cruel, to make me responsible? Just to weaken me, make me prove my character? So I waited, to get my hands on that safety deposit box. But I would have waited anyway. You want to show who's stronger, Bev? Nobody's stronger than me, goddamn it. When nothing is left, when everything is gone and disappeared, I'll be here.
Who's stronger now, you son-of-a-

You and me. We're alike.

I say they don't mind. If they knew I smuggled this on the plane? And sat there sweating like in that movie Midnight Express. Did you see that?
I just mean they don't mind that I smoke pot. Mom kind of does. I think cause Dad smokes pot too, and she wishes he didn't.

Hurry, okay?

Dumpster over there?

I think you smell that dumpster.

No.
That'd be so great. I just smoked my last bowl and I really need to get fucked up.
I really need to get fucked up --

Phantom of the Opera, 1925.
They're showing it with the scene in color restored.
I guess.

Don't suppose I could eat in here?
Right.
When you eat meat, you ingest an animal's fear.
Fear.

Your body goes through a whole chemical process when it experiences fear.

big deal?

I didn't tell you about the parakeets?

The heat. It was too hot. They were dying from the heat.
These are tropical birds, all right?
What, is she smoking a cigar?

Hi, Uncle Charlie.

Did you see Bill and Jean?

Why would he do that? Not like he couldn't drink at home. Unless you were riding his ass.
Really.
Oblivion.
Wait, wait, wait, I'm missing something. Why do you care about a safety deposit box?
You're such a fucking cynic.
Okay, what about the safety deposit box?
And you only had Ivy call me today?
Maybe he needed some time away from you.
Good old unfathomable Dad.
You don't want her here.
They're called Native Americans now, Mom.
It's what they like to be called.
In fact, they are.
Why's it so hard to call people --
She may be an Indian, but she makes the best goddamn apple pie I ever ate.
And now you get biscuits and gravy.
I'm very dutiful, Mom, I call, I write, I send presents --
Presents on birthdays, Mother's Day --
Well, you're seeing her now.
That is wildly unfair.
I'd prefer to think my parents loved all their children equally.
What was I supposed to do?! Colorado gave Bill twice the money he was making at TU --
You think Daddy wouldn't have jumped at the chance Bill got?
Daddy gave me his blessing.
Now you're going to tell me the true story, some terrible shit Daddy said behind my back?
Daddy never said anything like that to you. What a load of absolute horseshit.
Are you high?
I mean literally. You taking something?
Listen to me: I will not go through this with you again.
AM about people in your backyard?
The police, all the rest of it?
So now it's okay to get hooked because you have a reason.
I don't want to know if you are or not, I'm just saying I won't go --
Because of your mouth.
Are you in a lot of pain?
I'm not yelling at you.
I'd forgotten about the lightning bugs.
We have copies.
It wasn't that big a deal.
Those are small circles.
Jean go to bed?
Will you shut up about that fucking book?! You are just dripping with envy over these thirty poems my father wrote back in the late sixties, for God's sake. Y'hear yourself?
My father didn't write anymore for a lot of reasons, but critical opinion was not one of them, hard as that may be for you to believe.
I'm sure that's what you tell Sissy, too, so she can comfort you, reassure you, "No, Billy, you haven't done anything."
They're all symptoms of your male menopause, whether it's you struggling with the "creative question," or screwing a girl who still wears a retainer.
I know her stupid name -- do me the courtesy of recognizing when I'm demeaning you.
Psychoanalyze me right now, I skin you.
"Your methods." Thank you, Doctor, but I actually don't need any help from my mother to feel rage.
The subject is me! I am the subject, you narcissistic motherfucker! I am in pain! I need help!
You can't do it, can you? You can't talk about me for two seconds --
You do understand that it hurts, to go from sharing a bed with you for twenty-three years to sleeping by myself.
Oh, men always say shit like that, as if the past and the future don't exist.
It's just horseshit, to avoid talking about the things they're afraid to say.
Like what?
When did we visit this to begin with?
You're right. I'll just hunker down for a cozy night's sleep upstairs.
Mom?
Mom, wake up, the sheriff's here.
Mom.    The sheriff is here.

I guess we'll stop on the way.
I used to go out with that boy.
In high school. He was my prom date.
Day of the prom, his father got drunk and stole his car, stole his own son's car, went somewhere, Mexico.
So we got a six-pack and broke into the chapel, stayed up all night talking and kissing. Now here he is, showing me --
It's so surreal. Thank God we can't tell the future. We'd never get out of bed.
Listen to me: die after me, all right?

-- uh-huh --

Like your father drowning himself.

-- but what I think doesn't matter.

Mom?! Let's eat!

when we checked her in the psych ward, that stunt she pulled?
